stem: The nurse is preparing to perform sterile wound irrigation. Place the following steps in the correct order.

options.text: Irrigate the wound from the cleanest area to the dirtiest with constant pressure.
Perform hand hygiene and don sterile gloves.
Perform hand hygiene and don clean gloves to remove the old dressing.
Pat the surrounding skin dry with sterile gauze.
Fill a syringe with sterile irrigation solution and attach an angiocatheter.

rationale.correct: The correct sequence ensures asepsis and effective wound cleansing. (1) Donning clean gloves and performing hand hygiene prior to removing the old dressing minimizes the risk of introducing microorganisms into the wound. (2) Sterile gloves and hand hygiene are crucial for maintaining asepsis during the irrigation procedure. (3) Filling a syringe with sterile irrigation solution and attaching an angiocatheter prepares the irrigation equipment. (4) Irrigating from the cleanest area to the dirtiest utilizes gravity to facilitate the removal of contaminants and prevent recontamination of the cleansed area. This technique minimizes the risk of infection. (5) Patting the surrounding skin dry with sterile gauze prevents maceration, which can compromise skin integrity and increase the risk of infection.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect sequences compromise asepsis and irrigation effectiveness. Irrigating from the bottom up allows gravity to wash contaminants into the clean area, increasing infection risk. Failing to dry the surrounding skin can lead to maceration and skin breakdown. Performing steps out of order increases the risk of contamination.
clinicalPearls: Maintaining appropriate irrigation pressure is crucial for effective wound cleansing. Too much pressure can damage tissue, while too little pressure may not remove debris effectively.
Assess the wound for tunneling or undermining before irrigation to ensure thorough cleansing of all areas.
Document the type and amount of drainage, as well as the client's tolerance of the procedure, to monitor wound healing and identify potential complications.

questionTrap.trap: Forgetting the importance of hand hygiene and glove changes.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that hand hygiene and appropriate glove use are essential to prevent infection during wound care procedures. Changing gloves between removing the old dressing and performing the irrigation helps maintain asepsis.

mnemonic.title: Clean to Dirty
mnemonic.expansion: Irrigate wounds from the cleanest area to the dirtiest to prevent recontamination.

reviewUnits.heading: Wound Care: Irrigation
reviewUnits.body: Sterile wound irrigation is performed to remove debris and promote healing. Proper technique and asepsis are essential.
